questions.text: Which of the following types of cataract would be present in a patient after a blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
A rosette cataract typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma).

In blunt trauma, there may be minute ruptures in the lens capsule resulting in an influx of aqueous humor, leading to hydration and subsequent opacification of the lens. Commonly there is posterior subcapsular opacification in a flower shape along the posterior sutures. Hence it is called rosette cataract.

Iridodialysis occurs due to dehiscence of the iris from the ciliary body at its root. The pupil becomes D-shaped.

The following image shows a rosette cataract.

Apart from this, blunt trauma can cause a ring-shaped anterior subcapsular opacity underneath the Vossius ring. 

Other options:

(a) Sunflower cataract: Sunflower cataract is associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body. It is not related to blunt trauma.

(c) Christmas tree cataract: Christmas tree cataract is often seen in cases of myotonic dystrophy, a genetic neuromuscular disorder. It is not related to blunt trauma.

(d) Sparkle cataract: It does not correspond to a well-defined category of cataract associated with blunt trauma or any other specific condition.

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The swollen area in the given image and the clinical scenario is suggestive of vocal nodules.

Vocal nodules are also known as singer’s or screamer's nodes. It is present at the junction of anterior one-third with the posterior two thirds. It is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus is subjected to maximum trauma.

Vocal nodules occur due to vocal trauma when person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities. They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.

Nodule:

  • Early stages soft, reddish and oedematous swellings
  • Later stages - greyish or white in colour

Symptoms:

  • Hoarseness
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Pain in the neck on prolonged phonation

Treatment:

  • Educating the patient in proper use of voice.
  • Surgery is required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. They are excised with precision.

Other options:

Option A: Vocal polyp is caused by sudden shouting which results in hemorrhage and edema of the vocal cord.Affected individuals present with hoarseness of voice and diplophonia(double voice). Other factors associated with it are allergy and cigarette smoking. It presents as a benign swelling on the free edge of the vocal cord. 

Option B: Vocal cysts: These are retention cysts due to blockage of seromucinous glands of the laryngeal mucosa. They occur in the false vocal cords.

Option D: Reinke's edema is the collection of fluid in Reinke's space. Affected individuals present with diffuse swelling of the vocal cords. Treatment involves the removal of gelatinous collection by a longitudinal incision on the vocal cord.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and drowsiness. He later developed dizziness and altered consciousness. His mother reports that he had consumed palm fruit on their recent trip to Kerala and has not been feeling well since then. Keeping the patient's history in mind, which of the following viruses should be considered in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, headaches, myalgia, drowsiness, dizziness and altered consciousness, with a history of consuming palm fruit is likely to have been infected with the Nipah virus.

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted by animals to humans. 

It is an emerging paramyxovirus that belongs to the genus Henipavirus. It has caused disease in humans who have had contact with infected animals. 

It has a wide range of hosts and is associated with high mortality rates. Its natural host is a certain species of fruit bat while pigs may be an intermediate host for transmission to humans.
Its transmission can occur by the following methods:

  • Unprotected exposure to the secretions from the pigs, or unprotected contact with the tissue of a sick animal.
  • Consumption of fruits or fruit products (such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats of the family Pteropodidae.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions.
  • The incubation period ranges from 4 to 14 days.

Patients present with symptoms of headaches, myalgia, vomiting, and sore throat. This is followed by the onset of encephalitis, which manifests as dizziness, drowsiness, and altered consciousness. Patients may also present with acute respiratory distress. Encephalitis and seizures occur in severe cases, progressing to coma within 24 to 48 hours. 

Diagnosis is by means of real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) from bodily fluids and antibody detection via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) methods. The virus can be isolated by cell culture.

There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 μm) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

 

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer in cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis which has a center of abscess that contains thick colored brown pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with complaints of itching and a foreign body sensation in his eye. Upon examination, a shield ulcer is observed. The condition commonly associated with these findings is?
questions.solution:
Considering the symptoms of itching and foreign body sensation in the eye, and the presence of a shield ulcer, the most likely condition in this context is Spring catarrh.

Spring catarrh, or vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic form of allergic conjunctivitis. It typically occurs seasonally, often in the spring and summer. It presents with symptoms such as itching, foreign body sensation, and mucous discharge. While shield ulcers are not the primary feature of spring catarrh, severe and chronic cases may lead to corneal complications, including ulcers.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 
  • Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

Other options:

Tuberculosis is not commonly associated with a shield ulcer in the eye. Ocular tuberculosis can manifest in various ways, but itching and a shield ulcer are not typical features.

Autoimmune conditions can affect the eyes, but a shield ulcer in a child would not be a common presentation for autoimmune diseases.

Trachoma is an eye infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It can lead to chronic inflammation, scarring, and the development of a shield ulcer. However, trachoma is more commonly associated with chronic conjunctivitis and trichiasis (in-turned eyelashes) than with a shield ulcer.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is brought with failure to pass meconium since birth. The baby's abdomen is markedly distended and he aspirates on feeding. Rectal suction biopsy shows a lot of hypertrophied nerve bundles with increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of failure to pass meconium and a markedly distended abdomen along with a biopsy showing aganglionosis suggests a likely diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease/congenital aganglionic megacolon.

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder of the enteric nervous system. Normally, the enteric neuronal plexus develops by neural crest cells migrating to the colon wall. When there is a mutation in tyrosine kinase receptor RET, it results in premature arrest of this regular migration from the cecum to the rectum. This results in the lack of Auerbach and Meissner submucosal plexus in the distal intestinal segment (aganglionosis) causing hypertonicity of the bowel wall. Thus, there is a functional obstruction in the distal segment that also results in massive dilatation of the proximal segment (megacolon). 

      Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The onset of constipation can be seen at birth. Patients present with intermittent attacks of fever and pain due to intestinal obstruction from the retained feces. Complications include enterocolitis and bowel perforation. 

A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and shows increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. Other investigations include anorectal manometry and barium contrast enema. 

Surgical intervention is the only definitive treatment available.

Other options:

Option B: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis generally presents as new-onset regurgitation and projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A firm abdominal mass and abnormal left-to-right hyperperistalsis can be seen. Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography. 

Option C: Wilkie syndrome, otherwise known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome, occurs due to the compression of the third duodenal segment against the aorta by this artery. Diagnosis is by radiological demonstration of duodenal cutoff along with proximal duodenal dilatation. 

Option D: Functional constipation, otherwise known as fecal withholding, is the intentional or subconscious withholding of stool. It usually starts after the neonatal period. Here daytime encopresis (passage of stools at inappropriate places after 4 years of age) is common.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
The lumbricals and interossei muscles are affected.

Lumbricals and interossei muscles through their attachments to the dorsal digital expansions, cause:

  • Flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Extension of the interphalangeal (IP) joints

In cases of ulnar nerve injury, these muscles may get atrophied leading to the extension of MCP joints and flexion of IP joints.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for 

  • First and second lumbricals
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

questions.text: The coding sequence present in the RNA molecule is CAAGGU. What will be the sequence in the DNA from where it is transcribed?
questions.solution:
During transcription, the DNA sequence GTTCCA serves as the template for synthesizing the RNA sequence CAAGGU.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

  • Adenine= Thymine, Guanine = Cytosine
  • Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

When DNA is transcribed into RNA, the process involves complementary base pairing. Adenine (A) in DNA pairs with thymine (T), but in RNA, thymine is replaced by uracil (U). Similarly, cytosine (C) in DNA pairs with guanine (G) in both DNA and RNA. During transcription, RNA polymerase reads the DNA template and adds complementary RNA nucleotides accordingly.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant female in her first trimester was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following anticoagulant drugs can be used?
questions.solution:
For a pregnant female with deep vein thrombosis, Enoxaparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant in the first trimester.

Unfractionated or low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) is the preferred anticoagulant in the first trimester of pregnancy as it is a large molecule and cannot cross the placenta.

The choice of anticoagulants  in pregnancy:

Period of gestation Anticoagulant
Till 12 completed weeks LMWH or UFH
13 to 36 weeks Warfarin
36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery LMWH or UFH
6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

 

If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves

questions.text: A male patient presented to the OPD with a rash on his trunk. On examination, there is an eschar in the trunk region. Regional lymphadenopathy can also be noted. He reports that he recently experienced a mite bite during a camping trip in that area. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of eschar and lymphadenopathy following a mite bite on the trunk region is scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection transmitted through the bite of infected mites found in areas with heavy vegetation. The characteristic eschar (a black, necrotic lesion) at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy, is a hallmark feature of scrub typhus.

Option (b): Endemic typhus - Endemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia typhi, typically presents with fever, rash, and headache but does not commonly result in eschar formation.

Option (c): Epidemic typhus - Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by body lice and typically presents with fever, rash, and severe systemic symptoms but does not cause eschar formation.

Option (d): Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever - Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted by ticks, may present with rash and systemic symptoms but does not commonly produce eschar at the site of the tick bite.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female complained of fatigue for the past 1 year along with incidences of bleeding gums. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly and her hb level was noted to be 8gm/dl. Immature cells were seen in the peripheral smear.  Her blood workup showed a Total leucocyte count (TLC) of  1,50,000/microL.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with fatigue, bleeding gums, massive splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings are suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia(CML).

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder with the peak incidence in the fifth to sixth decade of life. The chimeric BCR-ABL gene is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation(Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene distinguishes CML from other myeloproliferative disorders and is detected by fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Clinical features:

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Peripheral blood:

  • Leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3, which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells.
  • Platelet count is usually increased

Bone Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular marrow because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors. There is usually an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
  • There is also an increase in megakaryocytes which usually include small, dysplastic forms and erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers. Typically there is an increased reticulin deposition, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course.

Sea-blue histiocytes - These are scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled,green-blue cytoplasm

 

Other options: 
Acute leukemias have a presence of immature blast cells in the bone marrow and peripheral smear usually (>20%) which is not seen in this patient. 

ALL lymphoblast cells have Tdt positive which is due to DNA polymerase. These cells can be B cell or T cell subtype. They are distinguished by cell surface markers. CD 10, 19, 20 are positive on B cells while CD2-8 are positive on T cell ALL.  

AML has positive staining for myeloperoxidase and auer rods are seen in the cytoplasm.
CLL is a disease seen in elderly patients(>65) and peripheral smear will show smudge cells.

questions.text: In the case of a suspected infective endocarditis patient, microscopic examination reveals the presence of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains as shown in the image below. What will be the etiological agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus viridans is a group of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, often a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in cases of subacute bacterial endocarditis.

Streptococcus viridans is a part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and upper respiratory tract. They are alpha-hemolytic, meaning they cause partial hemolysis on blood agar, resulting in a greenish colouration of the agar, hence the name "viridans," which means "green" in Latin.

Although Viridans streptococci are typically susceptible to penicillin, certain strains may exhibit resistance. Therefore, it is crucial that when dealing with endocarditis, the specific strain responsible is identified, and its sensitivity to antibiotics is assessed. This ensures the selection of suitable antibiotics at effective bactericidal levels for treatment.

questions.text: Reservoir for Kala azar is ?
questions.solution:
In India, humans are considered the main reservoir for kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis). 

Kala azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection, mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex that includes L. donovani and L. infantum. These organisms are transmitted by sandflies. 

Clinical features of kala-azar: 

  • Moderate- to high-grade fever with chills and rigors
  • Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly
  • Anemia
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Pedal edema, ascites, due to hypoalbuminemia
  • Epistaxis, gastrointestinal bleed, and retinal hemorrhages, due to thrombocytopenia

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used modality is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by rapid immunochormatographic test. 

Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. Other drugs useful in treating the condition are sodium stibogluconate, meglumine antimoniate, paromomycin, and miltefosine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T tubule?
questions.solution:
Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T tubule.

Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated calcium channel situated on the membrane of T-tubules within muscle cells. It works as a voltage sensor, it detects cell membrane depolarization triggered by an action potential. When depolarization occurs, DHPR undergoes a structural alteration, which then prompts the activation of the ryanodine receptor (RyR). This activation results in the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, instigating the process of muscle contraction.

Other options:

Ryanodine receptor (RyR): is present on the membrane of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) in muscle cells. Upon activation by calcium influx through DHPRs, RyRs release stored calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm, thereby initiating muscle contraction.

SERCA: is an ATPase enzyme situated on the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane, that actively transports calcium ions from the cytoplasm back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum during muscle relaxation. This process facilitates the reduction of cytoplasmic calcium levels, enabling muscle relaxation after contraction and preparing it for subsequent contraction cycles.

Troponin complex acts as a key regulatory switch in the excitation-contraction coupling process, ensuring that muscle contraction occurs only when calcium ions are present and that relaxation occurs when calcium levels decrease.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to acute liver failure?
questions.solution:
From all of the given options, Toxicity from Amanita phalloides (wild mushrooms) can result in substantial acute liver failure as they contain highly hepatotoxic amatoxins.

Amanita phalloides (wild mushrooms) toxicity: Mushroom poisoning presents with signs of parasympathetic excess. Signs and Symptoms include Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, bloody vomitus and stools, enlarged tender liver and jaundice, oliguria, pulmonary oedema, mental confusion, convulsions, and coma.

Organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphates commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. Toxicity occurs by excessive inhalation of vapours, ingestion, or percutaneous absorption. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms. Diarrhoea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm and Bradycardia are some of the clinical symptoms of this poisoning.

Morphine poisoning:  Presents with a triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis). Toxicity can lead to respiratory and mental status depression, analgesia, miosis, orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting, histamine release resulting in localized urticaria and bronchospasm, ileus secondary to decreased GI motility, and urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone.

Belladonna poisoning: Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. Clinical features are Delirium, slurred speech, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma, photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light, arrhythmia, tachycardia, and hypertension. Agitation and delirium are the most serious problems in such patients. The pupils are often dilated and poorly reactive to light.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the ER due to a suspected stroke. The patient has difficulty forming words but can make noises and give expressions as if he understands the questions asked. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Broca's aphasia.

In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Other options: 

Option A: Wernicke's aphasia is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired. The speech is easy and fluent but it is full of jargon and neologisms(non-existent words) that make little sense. Damage to the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus(area 22) or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia.  

Option C: Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking are impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibres connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency.

The most common cause of blindness in adults, is however, cataract.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of childhood blindness, particularly in developing countries. Lack of sufficient vitamin A can lead to conditions like xerophthalmia, which includes night blindness and can progress to more severe forms, ultimately causing irreversible damage to the cornea and leading to blindness. 

Other options:

(a) Refractive error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism, can cause vision problems, but they are usually correctable with glasses or contact lenses. While refractive errors can affect children's vision, they are not typically a direct cause of childhood blindness. 

(c) Retinopathy of prematurity: Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a condition that primarily affects premature infants and is related to abnormal blood vessel development in the retina. While it can lead to vision impairment or blindness in severe cases, it is not as prevalent as vitamin A deficiency, especially on a global scale. 

(d) Injuries: While injuries can certainly lead to vision impairment or blindness in children, they are not as prevalent on a population level as vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy presented with a two-day history of fever and abscess over the neck. The mother reveals that the child had similar recurrent infections in the past. The dihydrorhodamine test (DHR) was found to be positive. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and positive dihydrorhodamine test (DHR) most likely suggests chronic granulomatous disease.

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency in NADPH oxidase which is important in respiratory or oxidative bursts. In CGD, there is an increased risk of catalase-positive species (Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Aspergillus spp, etc.) leading to granulomas. The condition usually manifests in the first year of life with recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms.  

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs.

Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test. The yellow-coloured Nitroblue tetrazolium dye is converted to a purple insoluble substance (positive) in the presence of oxidative burst by the free oxygen radicals so formed. A negative test (yellow color remains) is seen in CGD.

Individuals with CGD will exhibit diminished or absent fluorescence in the DHR test, indicating impaired ROS production by phagocytes. This result confirms the diagnosis of CGD and aids in distinguishing it from other conditions with similar symptoms. It can also assess the effectiveness of treatments like bone marrow transplantation or gene therapy in restoring normal phagocyte function.

Other options:

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency due to a disorder of the phagolysosome function of leukocytes, leading to delayed microbial clearance. In addition, there is a disorder of melanin (albinism), nerve defects, and bleeding disorders.

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a primary immunodeficiency with a disorder of both cellular and humoral immunity. Persons with SCID are susceptible to recurrent severe infections caused by a wide variety of pathogens and usually do not survive beyond the first year of life without a stem cell transplant.

Tuberculosis is a bacterial disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is characterized by the formation of granulomas as an immune response to contain the infection. Tuberculosis presents with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Histopathology reveals caseous necrosis with multinucleated giant cells. Common manifestations include fever, night sweats, anorexia, weakness, and weight loss. Blood investigations may reveal anemia with leukopenia, lymphopenia, neutrophilic leukocytosis, leukemoid reactions, and polycythemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with easy fatiguability and was diagnosed as iron deficiency anemia. She was advised to take oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following should not be taken along with her iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Absorption of iron is decreased by tannates found in tea.

Tea contains compounds called tannins, which are polyphenolic compounds. These tannins have been shown to inhibit the absorption of non-heme iron from plant-based foods. Non-heme iron is the type of iron found in plant foods and is not as easily absorbed by the body as heme iron, which is found in animal-based foods.

Tannins bind to iron in the gastrointestinal tract, forming complexes that are poorly absorbed by the body. This can lead to decreased absorption of dietary iron, potentially contributing to iron deficiency if tea is consumed in large quantities, particularly with meals. The inhibitory effect of tea on iron absorption is more pronounced when consumed during meals rather than between meals.

In contrast, substances like ascorbic acid (found in fruits like amla) can enhance the absorption of non-heme iron, while certain foods like lime juice and sprouts don't significantly affect iron absorption.

Iron absorption:

Increased by ascorbic acid, citric acid, amino acids and sugars in the diet.
Decreased by phosphates, carbonates, oxalates, and tannates.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labelled 2?
questions.solution:
The plane marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The subcostal plane is an anatomical reference plane used in clinical and surgical practice. It is defined as a horizontal plane passing through the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage bilaterally. The 10th costal cartilage corresponds approximately to the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The costal cartilages are extensions of the ribs that articulate with the sternum anteriorly. The 10th costal cartilage is the cartilage of the 10th rib.

In the given image, structure 2 represents the subcostal plane, which corresponds to the level of the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage. Since the 10th costal cartilage is at the level of the upper border of L3, it indicates that the subcostal plane is also at the level of the upper border of L3.

questions.text: What is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle is the S phase.

The replication of the DNA genome occurs only at a specified time period during the cell cycle. This period is referred to as the synthetic or S phase. The S phase is separated from the mitotic, or M phase, by nonsynthetic periods referred to as gap 1 (G1) and gap 2 (G2) phases, occurring before and after the S phase, respectively. The cell prepares for DNA synthesis in G1, and for mitosis in G2.

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-M phase. Cells in the G2 or M phase do not have time to repair DNA damage that occurs before they start to divide. This affects mitosis, leading to catastrophe.

Cells become gradually less sensitive to radiation in the G1 phase to the early S phase and are least sensitive in the late S phase.

The most radiosensitive cell in the blood is the lymphocyte.

The least radiosensitive cell in the blood is the platelet.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of blurring of vision. On examination, you note that there are aqueous flares with numerous keratic precipitates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The features of aqueous flares and keratic precipitates indicate a diagnosis of Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI).

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. It is normally seen in middle-aged people who may complain of symptoms such as blurring of vision and persistent floaters.

Heterochromia iridis (the affected eye is hypochromic/hyperchromic) is noted in FHI. Rubeosis iridis and posterior subcapsular cataract are also fairly common findings.

On examination, stellate keratic precipitates known as endothelial dusting are seen. Tiny crystals (Russell bodies) and iris nodules (Koeppe nodules)  may also be found on the iris surface. Iris atrophy which appears as a smooth-looking iris can also be seen. 

Long-term monitoring is indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. 

The below image shows an example of heterochromia iridis (the left eye is hypochromic when compared to the right eye).

Other options:

(a) Intermediate uveitis: Intermediate uveitis primarily involves inflammation in the vitreous humor, which is the jelly-like substance in the middle of the eye. It is less likely to present with aqueous flares and keratic precipitates, making it an incorrect option.

(c) Posterior uveitis: Posterior uveitis involves inflammation in the posterior segment of the eye, including the choroid and retina. Aqueous flares and keratic precipitates are less likely to be observed in posterior uveitis, making it an incorrect option.

(d) Toxoplasma uveitis: Toxoplasma uveitis is a specific type of uveitis caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. While it may involve the anterior or posterior segment of the eye, the presence of aqueous flares and keratic precipitates is not specific to Toxoplasma uveitis alone.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is_____.
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells :

  • RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
  • The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are not diagnostic for any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:
    • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • Sarcomas

Hodgkin's lymphoma:

  • The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms including Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.
  • It is characterized by a variable number of RS cells surrounded by an inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils in different proportions, depending on the HL histologic subtype.
  • The interaction between the RS cell and these background inflammatory cells with their associated cytokine release is important in the development and progression of HL.

Option A: A peripheral blood smear showing numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). There is also the presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Option C: Histopathology of human papillomavirus lesion shows koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. 

Option D: In chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the peripheral smear contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.

questions.text: The triad of Situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis indicates the diagnosis of __________.
questions.solution:
This clinical triad is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). Patients with PCD (also called immotile cilia syndrome) have the Kartagener triad, characterized by:

  1. Situs inversus totalis
  2. Bronchiectasis
  3. Chronic sinusitis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia

  • Defects in ciliary motor proteins lead to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.
  • Ciliary function is necessary during development to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. In its absence, their location becomes a matter of chance. As a result, approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome, marked by situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality along with chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.
  • Males with this condition tend to be infertile, as a result of sperm dysmotility due to impaired sperm flagella function.

Other options:

Churg-Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.

Cystic fibrosis -  It is a multisystem disorder caused by the dysfunction of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR). It is an autosomal recessive trait with multiple clinical manifestations involving GIT, respiratory tract, pancreas, genitourinary tract and sweat glands.

Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter is present in skeletal muscles and adipose tissues?
questions.solution:
GLUT-4 is present in skeletal muscle cells and adipose tissues.

Glucose transporters, also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitative diffusion. Facilitative diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions through the cell membrane by them binding chemically to a carrier/ transport protein that is responsible for their movement across the cell membrane.

GLUT-4 is a transport protein present in adipocytes. When there is a rise in blood glucose level, insulin secreted by the pancreatic beta cells binds to its receptors on the plasma membrane of adipocytes. Upon binding of insulin to its receptor, activation of the receptor's tyrosine-kinase domain occurs. This activation starts a protein activation cascade leading to the translocation of GLUT4 to the plasma membrane.

Once translocation occurs and GLUT4 is inserted into the plasma membrane, facilitated diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into the cell occurs.

Other options:

Option B: GLUT-2 is found in the liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, and kidney. Its function is the rapid uptake or release of glucose.

Option C: GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine and is involved in the absorption of fructose.

Option D: SGLT-1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter present in the small intestine and kidney that is involved in the active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian presents with fatigue and weakness that have been present for a few months. On physical examination, pallor is noted. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL and MCV is increased at 110 fL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is megaloblastic anemia, given the patient's vegetarian diet, macrocytosis, and low hemoglobin level.

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate. Vegetarians are at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency because vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products. Other conditions can also cause megaloblastic anemia, such as celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis. Other causes of high MCV, such as liver disease, alcoholism, and hypothyroidism.

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by a low hemoglobin level and a microcytic (small cell) anemia. Iron is essential for the production of hemoglobin, and a deficiency of iron can lead to a decrease in hemoglobin levels. However, IDA is typically associated with a low MCV, not a high MCV.

In Aplastic anemia the bone marrow does not produce enough progenitor cells. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases, medications, and radiation. Aplastic anemia can lead to a decrease in all types of blood cells and is associated with a low MCV and a low hemoglobin level, not a high MCV.

Thalassemia is a group of genetic blood disorders that affect the production of hemoglobin. It is characterized by a microcytic anemia. However, thalassemia is not typically associated with a high MCV.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with glaucoma. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin analogues are the drug of choice for glaucoma.  This class of anti-glaucoma drugs acts by increasing the uveo-scleral outflow.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog and a commonly used medication for glaucoma. Prostaglandin analogs are often preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing convenience. 

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first line in glaucoma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used anti-glaucoma medication. Other prostaglandin analogues are travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of HIV infection was initiated on Anti Retroviral Therapy consisting of Tenofovir 150mg, Lamivudine 300mg, and Dolutegravir 50mg once daily at night, and now he is subsequently diagnosed with TB and started on antitubercular therapy. What is the required dose adjustment in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this scenario where a patient on ART (under TLD regimen) is newly diagnosed with TB, the dosage of Dolutegravir is adjusted by adding 50mg in the morning. The dose modification is due to the drug Rifampicin(ATT regimen), which is a potent inducer of CYP3A4 activity. Dolutegravir is susceptible to this effect and its plasma concentration is affected which makes us increase the dose requirement. 

Meanwhile, the other drugs in the regimen, Lamivudine and Tenofovir are unaffected by the CYP3A4 activity of Rifampicin and do not require any dose modification.

Dolutegravir is an integrase inhibitor, used in HIV-1 and HIV-2, preventing the integration of viral DNA into the host chromosome. 

In a patient with coexistent tuberculosis and HIV, the preferred first-line ART regimen for all with age >10 years and weight >30kg is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir as FDC in a single pill once a day.

In a patient with HIV-TB co-infection, it is ideal to start the Tuberculosis treatment before initiating ART (as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months).

questions.text: There is an intracellular buildup of cholesterol and cholesterol esters/fats in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease, caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). MTTP is necessary to transfer lipids to the small intestine's nascent chylomicrons and Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL)  in the liver. In abetalipoproteinemia, there is an absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL (apoB containing lipoproteins), and deficient levels of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides.

Other options: 

Tendon xanthomas: Tendon xanthomas are nodules or plaques formed in tendons due to the accumulation of cholesterol and cholesterol esters and is associated with conditions like familial hypercholesterolemia.

Strawberry gallbladder: Strawberry gallbladder, also termed cholesterolosis, refers to the deposition of cholesterol within the mucosa of the gallbladder, resulting in a strawberry-like appearance. 

Niemann-Pick disease: occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid-laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. In Niemann Pick Type C, there is accumulation of cholesterol in lysosomes.

questions.text:
A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
Vmax decreases and Km is unchanged
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration (i.e, reversible), non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations-

  • Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 4-14 days. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 
  • Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and pale with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. Children with sickle-cell disease may also develop vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent B19V infection that results in pure red cell aplasia has been reported in a wide variety of immunosuppressed patients, including patients with congenital immunodeficiency, AIDS, and lymphoproliferative disorders and transplant recipients.
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

It is a clinical diagnosis that usually does not require investigations. However, in the case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese female presented to the clinic with Schizophrenia. Which of the following anti-psychotic drugs causes the least weight gain?
questions.solution:
Out of the following antipsychotics, Ziprasidone causes the least weight gain.

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic used primarily in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It works by blocking the activity of dopamine and serotonin receptors in the brain. Specifically, it acts as an antagonist at dopamine D2 receptors and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

The side effects of ziprasidone include orthostatic hypotension, QT prolongation, and minimal weight gain.

Ziprasidone causes prolongation of QT interval and hence should be avoided in patients with a history of cardiac arrhythmias and should not be given in combination with other drugs known to prolong the QT interval.

Atypical agents classified according to their metabolic risk potential:

  • Highest: clozapine, olanzapine
  • Intermediate: quetiapine, risperidone, paliperidone
  • Least: Aripiprazole, ziprasidone, iloperidone, asenapine

Clozapine causes the highest weight gain among all antipsychotics.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image above is Lim's forceps.

Lim's forceps are a type of surgical instrument used in ophthalmic procedures. They are designed for delicate manipulations within the eye during surgery. These forceps typically have fine tips and a delicate grip, allowing surgeons to handle delicate tissues with precision.

Other options:

McPherson suture tying forceps are commonly used in ophthalmic surgery for grasping and tying sutures. They have a fine, curved tip which allows surgeons to manipulate sutures within the eye or in areas where precision is required, such as in delicate eye surgeries like cataract surgery.

Corneoscleral forceps are specialized instruments used in eye surgery for handling the cornea and sclera, the outer layers of the eye. questions.text: During pregnancy,  ABO incompatibility does not occur due to which antibody?
questions.solution:
IgM antibodies cannot cross the placenta from the maternal to the fetal circulation. Therefore, they do not have a significant role in causing hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) or ABO incompatibility during pregnancy.

ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease in newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical. This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does. 

It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of a different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunisation (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which does not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, which cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the firstborn infant (A-O is more common than B-O).

questions.text: A patient comes to you with fears of becoming pregnant and presents a history of unprotected sex five days ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 5 days ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device(IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception in this case. It can be inserted within 5 days (120 hours) of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

IUCD (Intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 

Emergency contraceptives, also known as postcoital contraceptives are used to prevent conception after unprotected intercourse. They are interceptives. Their main action is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperm.

They include:

  • RU 486 (Mifepristone): 25 mg single dose is effective in 99.1% as a postcoital drug. 
  • Prostaglandins 
  • Copper T
  • Yuzpe method: Combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills are used as post-coitus contraceptives.

questions.text: What ECG change is associated with the use of the anti-tubercular drug Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Bedaquiline is associated with a prolonged QT interval.

Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB. Bedaquiline is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. 

Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism. It is largely deposited in tissues owing to its amphiphilicity. Resistance caused by mutations in efflux pumps and their regulators is also observed and is linked to the development of cross-resistance to clofazimine.

CYP3A4 is a major enzyme involved in the metabolism of bedaquiline.

Due to the high risk of QT prolongation, the FDA has issued a black box warning against the use of bedaquiline therefore having restricted use in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: A male patient presents with nasal obstruction, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and loss of smell. Endoscopic findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and the endoscopic findings points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis. 

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
    • Modified Young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort of complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

questions.text: What cells are present in the center of the lumen of venules?
questions.solution:
Red blood cells (RBCs) are typically found in the center of central veins, whereas white blood cells (WBCs) are predominantly located in the periphery of these veins.

RBCs tend to form a central column within the vessel due to their discoid shape and higher density compared to other blood components. This arrangement displaces leukocytes (white blood cells) towards the vessel's wall.

The positioning of leukocytes near the vessel wall facilitates their interaction with endothelial cells, aiding in the immune response to pathogens or injury as well as migration to sites of infection or injury. WBCs play a crucial role in immune surveillance and response to pathogens.

questions.solution:
Conn's syndrome presents with Metabolic alkalosis.

Patients with Conn's syndrome have primary hyperaldosteronism which results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It is associated with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with pain in his right ear. He is diagnosed with right sided otitis media after investigations. He also adds that he recurrently gets these ear infections. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in a 50 year old male with recurrent otitis media is most likely nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. It commonly occurs in males in the 5th to 7th decade. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex 
    • CN II - exophthalmos 
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Examination of the ear shows a dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows a Type B curve due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult suggests nasopharyngeal growth.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to the involvement of the CN X may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion.

questions.text: Which of the following studies progresses from cause to effect?
questions.solution:
A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. A well-designed cohort study is considered the most reliable means of showing an association between a cause or suspected risk factor and subsequent disease (or effect).

Types of epidemiological studies:

  • Observational studies - allow nature to take its course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.
  1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population- (hypothesis formulation).
  2. Analytical studies - go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables- (hypothesis testing).
  • Ecological studies
  • Cross-sectional studies
  • Case-control studies
  • Cohort studies
  • Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences- (hypothesis confirmation).
  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials      

Other options:

Option A: Although case-control studies are inherently analytical, they are not longitudinal. Longitudinal studies involve the collection of variables about a subject over an extended duration.

Option C: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention is given to a group of patients participating in the study and compared to another group of patients with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied. It uses patients as the unit of study.

Option D: An ecological study is a type of analytical study that analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called a correlational study, and it uses the population as a unit of study. Longitudinal studies involve the collection of variables about a subject over an extended duration.

questions.text: A child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around hair follicles and is not allowing anyone to move his limbs because of pain. He also has tender nodules over the chest, as seen in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C. Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline that are used in the synthesis of collagen. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to the formation of defective collagen. 

Defective collagen results in capillary hemorrhages which may present as generalized bleeding tendency. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Subperiosteal hemorrhages cause acute pain and swelling mimicking acute osteomyelitis. 

Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, also known as scorbutic rosary. Rickets also presents with similar nodules at the costochondral junctions known as rachitic rosary. They can be differentiated as scorbutic rosary is more sharply angulated and are painful.

questions.text: Which among the following is a role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA)?

choices.text: Review and consolidate reports received from the health workers

Organize and conduct tubectomy and vasectomy camps
Act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits

questions.solution:
It is the role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA) is to act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with formal education of up to eighth grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Other roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract /sexually transmitted infection 
  • To facilitate access to health care and healthcare-related services.
  • To arrange an escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform the sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community.
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign.

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements.

questions.text: A woman visits the gynaecology OPD for a scheduled ANC check-up. A 1st-trimester scan reveals that her child has anencephaly. This occurs due to the inability of neural tube closure at what weeks of intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. Neural tube defects (NTDs) result from the failure of the neural tube to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development.

Anencephaly is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP).

The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies. 400 μg of folic acid is given starting preconceptionally and continud throughout pregnancy(In cases with no prior history).

questions.text: Kinesin, Dyenin and Myosin proteins are examples of?
questions.solution:
Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are examples of molecular motors.

The molecular motors are the force-generating proteins as they move proteins, organelles, and other cell parts (collectively referred to as “cargo”) to all parts of the cell.

Kinesin:

  • The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule that moves its cargo toward the plus (“+”) ends of microtubules.
  • Some kinesins are associated with mitosis and meiosis.
  • Other kinesins perform different functions, and may also move cargo to the minus (“–”) end of microtubules.

 Dyneins:

  • They have two heads, with their neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
  • Cytoplasmic dyneins are similar to conventional kinesin, except they move particles and membranes to the minus (–) end of the microtubules.
  • Axonemal dyneins are present with the axonemes of the cilia. An axoneme consists of a unique arrangement of nine outer microtubule doublets and two inner microtubules ("9+2" arrangement). The coordinated dynein–microtubule interactions within the axoneme are responsible for the ciliary and sperm movement.

Myosins:

  • There are about 18 classes of myosins.
  • The heads of some myosin molecules (myosin II) bind to actin and produce motion by bending their neck regions.
  • Some myosin molecules (myosin V) may move the cargo, by walking along microfilaments, one head after the other.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following type of stridor will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child has croup, which would most likely be associated with biphasic stridor.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea. For e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. Inspiratory stridor is heard in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx. For e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your OPD with complaints of non-foul-smelling curdy white vaginal discharge accompanied by itching and burning. Microscopic examination revealed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What is the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of non-foul smelling curdy white vaginal discharge and budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae on microscopy are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis caused by Candida albicans. 

Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Vulvovaginal candidiasis occurs in conditions that decrease the normal genital microbiota(e.g., long-term antibiotic use), allowing the yeasts to proliferate and produce symptoms. 

Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

The clinical symptoms of vulvovaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching with vaginal pH <4.5. 

Diagnosis includes:

  • Wet smear with 10% KOH solution- shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae as seen in the image below:
  • Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae
  • Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odour.
  • Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.
  • CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

Treatment involves oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose or local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole miconazole, clotrimazole, vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3-6 days is effective.

The stapes is the smallest and medial most ossicle, which is stirrup-shaped, with two distinct limbs and a footplate attached to the oval window. It has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of the stapes in the oval window.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who is on antitubercular therapy (ATT) experiences red-green color discrimination issues. Which of the following ATT drugs is most likely responsible for this side effect?
questions.solution:
The most likely ATT drug responsible for the red-green color discrimination issue in this case is ethambutol. It is important to monitor patients on this drug for visual side effects and, if necessary, consider dosage adjustments or discontinuation under medical supervision.

Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. It is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

Option C: Pyrazinamide is more commonly associated with hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia. 

Option D: Rifampicinis known for causing orange discoloration of body fluids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with continuous discomfort in the right hypochondrium. Upon examination, an enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins is noted. The image below displays his CT radiograph. Additionally, he reports a history of spending a significant amount of time around pet dogs. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with  CT scan of the liver showing a hydatid cyst seen as a hypodense lesion with internal septation, suggests a diagnosis of Echinococcus granulosus. It is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases.

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary. The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

Investigation:

  • CT examination reveals a fluid density cyst, with frequent peripheral focal areas of calcification, which usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • Septation and daughter cysts may be visualised. The water-lily sign indicates a cyst with a floating, undulating membrane, caused by a detached endocyst.
  • May also show hyperdense internal septa representing a spoke wheel pattern within a cyst.
