questions.text: An 18-month-old child visited the ophthalmologist exhibiting a white eye reflex, and ultrasonography revealed an intraocular mass with calcifications. The family history indicated that the child's father had a similar condition and underwent the removal of one eye (enucleation). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of leukocoria, an intraocular mass with calcifications on ultrasound, and a positive family history, the most likely diagnosis is retinoblastoma (option b).

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that predominantly affects children, and early detection and treatment are crucial for better outcomes. point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. 

It most commonly presents with leukocoria followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy.Vincristine, Carboplatin, Etoposide are the choice of drugs for chemotherapy. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when the tumor involves more than half of the retina, optic nerve involvement, glaucoma, and anterior chamber involvement.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, It is used to measure the humidity/ moisture content in the air.

Sling Psychrometer has 2 mercury thermometers (wet and dry) in it. The wet bulb is moistened first with distilled water and the instrument is whirled/rotated standing with the back to the sun. The reading is noted twice.

Later the dry bulb is taken up for the reading and the relative air humidity is obtained by use of suitable tables and charts.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

  • A number of thermometers which employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.
  • These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.
  • The instruments used to measure air temperature are:
    • Dry bulb thermometers:
      • These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level
    • Wet bulb thermometers
      • These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.
    • Maximum thermometer
      • This is a mercury thermometer which has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb
    • Minimum thermometer
      • The liquid in this thermometer is spirit which has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it
    • Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer
      • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
      • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
      • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available
  • Globe thermometer:
    • It is used for the direct measurement of mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
    • It has a hollow metal bulb (6 inches diameter) which has a matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
    • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.
  • Kata thermometers:
    • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
    • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
    • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A patient presented with cheilitis, stomatitis, and a glove and stocking pattern of neuropathy. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described, including cheilitis, stomatitis, and glove and stocking pattern neuropathy, is most consistent with Vitamin B12 deficiency. This deficiency can lead to a condition known as pernicious anemia which presents with a variety of symptoms including those described.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy (glove and stocking pattern), as well as gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea. Additionally, vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which may present with cheilitis and stomatitis.

Other options:

(a) Niacin (B3) deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Cheilitis and stomatitis are common manifestations of pellagra, but glove and stocking pattern neuropathy are not typically associated with niacin deficiency.

(b) Thiamine (B1) deficiency: Thiamine deficiency can cause a condition known as beriberi, which can manifest with neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it usually does not present with dermatological symptoms like cheilitis and stomatitis.

(d) Riboflavin (B2) deficiency: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can cause glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) and cheilosis (cracks or sores at the corners of the mouth). While riboflavin deficiency can cause dermatological symptoms, it is less likely to cause rashes in sun-exposed areas and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man joins a pilgrimage to a shrine at a mountain peak. At the summit, he develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium. Which of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of acute mountain sickness and acetazolamide can be given for symptomatic relief.

Acetazolamide (125–250 mg twice a day), administered for 1 day before ascent and continued for 2 or 3 days is effective.It can also be used for prophylaxis.

Paresthesia and a tingling sensation are common side effects of acetazolamide.

Acute mountain sickness:

When individuals arrive first at a high, altitude, many develop transient 'mountain sickness'.This syndrome develops 8-24h after arrival at altitude and lasts 4-8 days.

Characterized by:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Cause: Appears to be associated with cerebral edema

The low PO2 at high altitude causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema. 

In high altitude cerebral edema, the capillary leakage in mountain sickness progresses to frank brain swelling, with ataxia, disorientation, and in some cases coma and death due to herniation of the brain through the tentorium.

Treatment:

  • Descent to a lower altitude
  • Diuretics like acetazolamide: inhibits carbonic acid anhydrase, and results in stimulated respiration, increased PaCO2, and reduced formation of CSF
  • Glucocorticoids are administered as well. Their mechanism of action is not clear.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea. Investigations revealed that his HbA1C is 10%. The likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea indicates malignant otitis externa.

It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC.
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient

The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complete anopia in the right eye. The lesion would be present in which specific anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
The most likely site of the lesion causing unilateral complete anopia in the right eye is (c) Right optic nerve. This suggests that there is a problem affecting the visual information from the right eye before the optic chiasma.

Unilateral complete anopia refers to complete blindness in one eye. To determine the location of the lesion, we need to understand the visual pathway:

Right optic radiation: The optic radiation transmits visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in the optic radiation typically lead to homonymous visual field defects (loss of vision on the same side in both eyes). Since the patient presents with unilateral anopia in the right eye, the optic radiation is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Optic chiasma: The optic chiasma is where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at the optic chiasma often result in bitemporal hemianopia, affecting the temporal visual fields of both eyes. Given that the patient's symptoms are unilateral, the optic chiasma is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Right optic nerve: The optic nerve carries visual information from the eye to the optic chiasma. A lesion in the right optic nerve would lead to unilateral blindness (anopia) in the right eye, making it a likely site of the lesion in this case.

Right optic tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the visual cortex. Lesions in the optic tract could lead to homonymous visual field defects. Since the patient's anopia is unilateral, the right optic tract is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 70-year- old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with diarrhoea following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhoea in nosocomial infections. It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to the colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in the stool are used as they are both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT)

Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases. Metronidazole is now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes for Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Defective Tyrosine transaminase is associated with _____.
questions.solution:
Defective Tyrosine transaminase is associated with type II tyrosinemia, known as Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia.

  • Type 1 tyrosinemia: also known as hepatorenal tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective enzyme is fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical features are liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odor in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 is known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. The defective enzyme is tyrosine transaminase. Clinical features are palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and mental retardation.
  • Type 3 is known as neonatal tyrosinemia. It is due to the deficiency of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Clinical features include normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures, and intermittent ataxia.

Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life.

questions.text: After consuming three cones of ice cream, a man notices that his ear feels colder than the central part of his body. Which area of the brain regulates body temperature?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus is responsible for regulating the body temperature.

The hypothalamus is the thermoregulatory centre of the body. It acts as a central command centre for thermoregulation, ensuring that the body maintains a relatively constant core temperature despite external temperature fluctuations.

  • The reflex responses triggered by cold originate from the posterior hypothalamus,
  • The reflex responses initiated by warmth primarily stem from the anterior hypothalamus.

Activation of the anterior hypothalamus leads to cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, while lesions in this area can result in hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimes rising to 43°C (109.4°F).

Stimulation of the posterior hypothalamus induces shivering, and animals with lesions in this region experience a decrease in body temperature toward that of the surrounding environment.

Hence, histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics?

choices.text: Inhibits the Na-CI pump in early distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-CI pump in late distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the descending limb of loop of Henle
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide-like diuretic. It inhibits Na+-Cl- symporter in the early distal tubule and increases the excretion of sodium and chloride.

Thiazide diuretics:

They may be used for the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, nephrolithiasis due to idiopathic hypercalciuria, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect. The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia. The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Mechanisms of antihypertensive action: Decreases plasma and ECF volume by diuresis thereby decreasing cardiac output. Even when the compensatory mechanisms restore the Na+ levels and plasma volume, a low BP is maintained by a reduction in total peripheral resistance. This reduction in total peripheral resistance is due to the persistence of a small sodium and volume deficit even after compensation. The decreased intracellular sodium is responsible for increased compliance of the vessel wall and a reduced response to constrictor stimulus.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

Advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension
  • Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: What do apoptotic bodies consist of?
questions.solution:
An apoptotic body is formed during the late stages of apoptosis when a cell undergoes controlled self-destruction. Apoptotic bodies contain all the cellular components such as organelles and fragmented DNA and are typically smaller than the cell undergoing apoptosis. 

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, plays a vital role in the normal development and renewal of tissues. It can be initiated by external triggers like cytotoxic T cells or inflammatory molecules, as well as internal factors such as DNA damage or cellular stress.

Mitochondria play a key role in processing signals that determine whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not. If there's a predominance of signals favoring cell death, mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization (MOMP) occurs, releasing cytochrome C and other proteins into the cytoplasm. These proteins then activate internal pathways leading to programmed cell death. 

Apoptosis has two pathways:

A. Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

  • Cell injury results in the release of cytochrome C and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria.
  • These then activate caspase 9 which causes nuclear fragmentation and formation of apoptotic bodies.

B. Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

  • In this pathway, activation of death receptors causes apoptosis by activating caspase-8.
  • Prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95).

questions.text: A 36-year-old chronic alcoholic male was diagnosed with amoebiasis and was started on anti-amoebic drugs. The patient later developed hypotension along with flushing, nausea, and vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of disulfiram-like reaction following medication taken to treat amoebiasis in this patient. In most cases, Metronidazole is used. It acts by forming free-radical metabolites.

It is well known to cause a disulfiram-like reaction when alcohol is taken during or within 3 days of therapy.

Metronidazole acts selectively against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It enters the cell and is reduced to form a nitro radical. This radical competes with the PFOR(pyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase) enzyme used by these organisms to carry out pyruvate metabolism(since these do not have mitochondria). It inhibits the cellular metabolism of these organisms, causing death.

Drugs causing disulfiram like reaction are :

  • Metronidazole
  • Cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine.

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant reactions like

  • Flushing
  • Sweating
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Headache.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency in SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
  • Deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP), which are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes.
  • In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

X-linked SCID.

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.  
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Other options:

Option A – Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency causes increased ammonia concentrations causing ataxia and death. It is one of the most common urea cycle disorders.

Option B– Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy, and hepatic fibrosis.

Option D-Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme deficiency leads to a disease called Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND)

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods with square ends with a central spore. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive rod with square ends giving it a characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

The image shows the characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis on Gram staining.

Bacillus anthracis is a category A bioterrorism agent which can cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–7 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

The image below shows necrotic eschar seen in anthrax:

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.

Fluid or pus from cutaneous lesions, pleural fluid, blood, or CSF can be cultured on:

  • Nutrient agar- frosted glass appearance
  • Gelatin stab culture- Inverted fir tree appearance
  • Blood agar- Non-hemolytic colonies
  • Solid medium with penicillin- String of pearls appearance

Other options:

Option A: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Burns infections
  • Opportunistic and nosocomial infections
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

Option D: Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, pigs, and other animals. Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever (Rising and falling fever). They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with skin lesions that are associated with loss of sensation. What is the most unstable form of the disease this patient has?
questions.solution:
The image shows punched-out anesthetic lesions characteristic of the borderline spectrum of leprosy. The most unstable form of leprosy is the borderline-borderline type.

This type is rarely seen as it rapidly upgrades towards tuberculoid or downgrades towards lepromatous, based on the immune status of the individual. However, clinical features may lag behind the immunological and histological findings. This leads to numerous skin lesions and with features of both ends of the spectrum. 

Lepromatous and tuberculoid types are the most stable.

questions.text: A patient presents with the findings as shown in the image below. What is the most likely voice abnormality that would be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients with this condition would present with rhinolalia clausa.

Adenoid hypertrophy occurs in response to allergens or infections. It is more common in children. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice).

They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining academic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, hitched-up upper lip, pinched-in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth.

Other options:

  • Rhinolalia aperta is hypernasality seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency etc.
  • Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.
  • Staccato voice is broken speech and is seen in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT?

choices.text: Inhibits the Na-CI pump in early distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-CI pump in late distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the descending limb of loop of Henle
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter.

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide-like diuretic. It inhibits the Na Cl symporter in the early distal tubule and increases the excretion of sodium and chloride.

Thiazide diuretics:

They may be used for the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, nephrolithiasis due to idiopathic hypercalciuria, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the NaCl co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect. The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia. The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Mechanisms of antihypertensive action: Decreases plasma and ECF volume by diuresis thereby decreasing cardiac output. Even when the compensatory mechanisms restore the Na+ levels and plasma volume, a low BP is maintained by a reduction in total peripheral resistance. This reduction in total peripheral resistance is due to the persistence of a small sodium and volume deficit even after compensation. The decreased intracellular sodium is responsible for increased compliance of the vessel wall and a reduced response to constrictor stimulus.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

Advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension
  • Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presented with pain and hearing loss after trauma to his right ear. Otoscopy reveals the presence of blood clots along with irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane. What is the next step in management in this case?

choices.text: Keep ear dry with systemic analgesics

questions.solution:
In this case, the presence of blood clots and irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane suggests traumatic injury to the ear. The initial management involves keeping the ear dry to prevent infection and further damage.

When a patient presents with pain and hearing loss after trauma to the ear, it's important to manage the condition appropriately. Systemic analgesics can be prescribed to alleviate pain.

Other options:

  • It's important to avoid introducing any foreign substances into the ear canal, such as ear drops or irrigation, as this can exacerbate the injury and increase the risk of infection.
  • Aspirating and performing audiometry may be considered later in the management process, once the acute phase has resolved and the extent of damage needs further evaluation.
  • Giving gentamicin and levofloxacin or other antibiotics is not indicated at this stage unless there are signs of infection, as prophylactic antibiotic use is generally not recommended due to the risk of promoting antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive male patient was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide and he developed fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following medications could be introduced instead of thiazide diuretics to prevent potassium depletion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and can causes hypokalemia. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used in this patient to prevent further potassium loss.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting. 

Other options:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting the Na-K-2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Used in cases of acute pulmonary edema, hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, and hypertension.

Adenosine is used for its antiarrhythmic properties, particularly in the treatment of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). It is fast-acting and has a short half-life. Adenosine does not directly influence potassium levels or diuresis.

Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide belongs to the class of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and functions as a diuretic by inhibiting bicarbonate ion reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. While acetazolamide may induce mild potassium depletion as a potential side effect, it is not typically utilized to counteract the potassium-depleting effects associated with thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for arthritis in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is the preferred drug of choice in the treatment of arthritis in Acute rheumatic fever. 

Aspirin is a noncompetitive, irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase(COX) enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. It can be effective in treating carditis and arthritis which are seen commonly in acute rheumatic fever.

Uses of aspirin:

  • Analgesic and antipyretic uses.
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Post myocardial infarction and stroke due to its antiplatelet action.
  • Prevention of preeclampsia

The treatment of Acute rheumatic fever is symptomatic.

  • Antibiotics:
    All people diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) should be administered antibiotics effective against the precipitating group A streptococcal infection. Penicillin is typically the preferred antibiotic.
  • Salicylates and NSAIDs:
    These can be used to alleviate symptoms such as arthritis, arthralgia, and fever once the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is confirmed. Aspirin is the first choice. It is typically prescribed at a dosage of 50–60 mg/kg per day, with a maximum dose of 80–100 mg/kg per day (4–8 g/day in adults), divided into 4–5 doses throughout the day.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution:
Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot’s spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that leads to corneal scarring and ultimately, blindness.

According to WHO grading, the order of progression is as follows:

  • XN: Night blindness
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B: Bitot's spot (It is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.) 
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Keratomalacia affecting less than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • X3B: Keratomalacia affecting greater than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • XS: Corneal scar
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus

Other options:

  • Option A: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.
  • Option C: Vitamin B1/thiamine deficiency leads to Beriberi(wet or dry beriberi) and Wernicke encephalopathy
  • Option D: Vitamin B3/niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by dementia, dermatitis, and diarrhea.

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. A diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis is made. What is the preferred treatment for this patient at this stage?
questions.solution:
Intermittent ptosis is considered one of the earliest signs of Myasthenia gravis. Pyridostigmine is the preferred treatment for symptomatic patients at this stage of the disease.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness. Hence the goal is to increase the duration of action of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase. The most commonly used anticholinesterase drug is pyridostigmine. 

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis 
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, Neuromyelitis optics, Systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases the activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission).
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with complaints of headache, seizures and blurred vision. His BP was recorded as 220/120 mmHg. Which of the following will be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypertensive crisis (BP > 160/110 mmHg). The preferred drug to manage a hypertensive patient in an emergency is IV labetalol.

Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a hypertensive crisis. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile.

Labetalol is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

It is available in oral form for the treatment of chronic hypertension and as an intravenous formulation for use in hypertensive emergencies. It can be used in the setting of a pregnancy-induced hypertensive crisis.

Other options: 

Option A: IV Hydralazine: It is a vasodilator used in the treatment of heart failure, and hypertensive emergencies, especially preeclampsia. The drug is used as a combination pill containing isosorbide dinitrate (BiDil) in the treatment of heart failure. The important side effect of hydralazine is drug-induced lupus.

Option B: Oral Nifedipine: It is a calcium channel blocker (CCB), a class of medications commonly used to lower blood pressure by relaxing the blood vessels. They work by blocking the influx of calcium into smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilation and reduced peripheral resistance. They are safer alternatives to use in pregnant patients with Asthma as they do not cause vasoconstriction and would not worsen it.

Option D: Oral Methydopa: Methyldopa is a selective alpha-2 receptor agonist and is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown above is a Blom-Singer prosthesis. Blom-Singer prosthesis and Panje prosthesis are types of tracheoesophageal prosthesis.

A tracheoesophageal prosthesis(TEP) involves a one-way valve that is inserted through a previously-created tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, the exhaled air is shunted through the TEP into the oesophagus, where it induces vibration of the upper oesophagal sphincter, which is responsible for phonation. It generates the most intelligible, fluent, natural-sounding voice in contrast to other laryngeal speech methods.

Other options:

Transoral pneumatic device is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

Electrolarynx produces vibrations that are transmitted through the skin toward the throat. The sound generated is converted into low-pitch speech by the vocal tract—palate, tongue, and teeth. The advantages are that is easy and quick to learn, while the disadvantages are that the voice is monotonous and the constant occupation of one hand.

Mendelsohn maneuver is a form of a supraglottic swallow. It is done by voluntarily holding the larynx at its maximum height to prolong the duration of the cricopharyngeal opening. It has been used to treat patients with pharyngeal dysphagia.

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the sinuses. What is the common name of this view?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shown above shows Towne's view.

Towne's view is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Other options:

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Submentovertical view/ Hirtz view/ basal view is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area. It is commonly used to get a better view of sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with hearing loss underwent an audiogram, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above Pure tone audiogram is characteristic of Otosclerosis.

In the above audiogram,

  • An air-bone gap is present.
  • BC > AC

This is suggestive of Conductive Hearing loss. In the above options, only Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Carhart’s notch is the characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz seen in otosclerosis. It disappears after successful stapes surgery.

PTA in Sensorineural hearing loss :

  • Shows no Air Bone gap.
  • Both BC and AC are in hearing loss range (>25 DB)

Other options:

  • Meniere’s disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying changes in the population of a country with time. This process is called the demographic cycle. Which of the following options best defines the correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: High expanding→ Early stationary → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining
High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

The demographic cycle is comprised of five stages and is as described below:

Stage 1: High stationary population - There is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

Stage 2: Early expanding population - There is a decline in the death rate that begins but the birth rate stays constant. Ex: Many countries in South Asia, and Africa are in this phase. 

Stage 3: Late expanding population - There is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase.

Stage 4: Low stationary population - There is a low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It can also result in zero population growth like in Austria (1980-85). Other examples: the UK, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium recorded a growth rate of 0.1 in 1980-85. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

Stage 5: Contracting population - The birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Ex: East European countries like Germany, and Hungary.

India is currently in the "late expanding" stage which is the third stage in the demographic cycle where declining death rates and declining birth rates are seen.

Another important concept of the demographic cycle is the demographic gap which is the difference between birth rate and death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both birth rate and death rate falls causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

questions.text: A boy, upon disturbing a bee hive, received several stings. After a few minutes, he developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. This is an example of ______.
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity. Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions.

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity:

  • These are also called allergic reactions or allergies.
  • They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals
  • IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors; reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators.
  • The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents; prostaglandins and leukotrienes; as well as cytokines.
  • The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation).
  • The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
  • It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase.

questions.text: A boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: Biopsy is the investigation of choice
Blood supply is mostly from the external carotid artery.

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen. The statement "Biopsy is the investigation of choice" is incorrect because in this condition, biopsy is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

It is a benign tumor, which commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. From here, the tumor grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (antral sign/Holman-Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions. Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. 

Given below is a CT image showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with an erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters can be used to measure the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period?
questions.solution:
Crude death rate measures the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period. 

Crude death rate = Number of deaths during the year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Other options:

Option B: The case fatality rate represents the killing power of the disease. Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

Option C: Proportional mortality rate is used to know the proportion of total death due to any particular cause. It does not indicate the risk of contracting or dying from the disease.

Option D: Specific death rate is used to identify particular groups or groups "at-risk" for preventive action. They help in comparison between different causes of death within the same population. 

Specific death rate due to cancer = Number of death from cancer during a calendar year X 1000/ Mid-year population

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about laryngomalacia?

choices.text: Patient will present with an inspiratory stridor
It is the most common congenital cause of stridor in children

questions.solution:
In laryngomalacia, stridor improves in prone position.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids. Due to the collapsing nature, stridor is increased in the supine position and decreased in prone position.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. He underwent a cataract surgery 1 month ago. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed a flower-petal appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. 

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop.

Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. 

Given below is the FFA image showing the classic flower-petal appearance, followed by an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak.

OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

Option D: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is bilateral disease affecting people who are above 50 years of age. It can be exudative or non-exudative types. There can be a gradual or sudden loss of vision depending on the type of AMD. Drusens (yellowish-white elevated spots caused by extracellular deposits in the macular region) of various types can be noted. FFA shows punctate hyperfluorescence due to the drusen.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs does not require any renal dose modification in those with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin is a competitive dipeptidyl peptidase - 4 inhibitor does not require any renal dose modification.  

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with very little renal clearance.  

It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or as combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.

Other options:

Saxagliptin and other DPP - 4 inhibitors circulate primarily in unbound form and are excreted largely unchanged in the urine. Renal dose modification is required in patients with reduced renal function.  

Repaglinide is a non-sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue. A proportion of the drug is eliminated by the kidney and dose modification is required.  

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue which is metabolised in the liver and the metabolites are excreted in the urine. Thus it requires dose modification in both renal and hepatic insufficiency.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain?
questions.solution:
The Plasmodium species that primarily affects the brain is Plasmodium falciparum. It causes severe forms of malaria, including cerebral malaria, which can lead to several neurological complications.

Cerebral malaria is diagnosed in the case of P. falciparum parasitemia with altered consciousness. Common features include seizures and hypoglycemia. Retinal haemorrhages, neurological findings like hemiplegia, absent or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign can also be seen.

All patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours.

questions.text: Which mutation is linked to the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.solution:
The mutation associated with the Philadelphia chromosome is a result of reciprocal translocation.

Fusion of BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22)translocation (Philadelphia chromosome. This is detected by cytogenetics, fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and occurs in Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML). To form the abnormal chromosome, part of the BCR (breakpoint cluster region) gene of chromosome 22 fuses with part of the ABL gene (encodes a tyrosine kinase) of chromosome 9, directing the synthesis of a chimeric protein that has unregulated tyrosine kinase activity and drives cell proliferation.

The peak incidence of CML is in the fifth to sixth decade.

  • Clinical features:
    • Anemia weight loss, and anorexia.
    • Splenomegaly
  • Peripheral blood:
    • Leukocytosis, exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3, which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
    • Blasts usually make up less than 5% of circulating cells.
  • Bone Marrow: 
    • Markedly Hypercellular with maturing granulocytic precursors, with an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
    • Low LAP score

 Image – Interphase FISH showing (9;22) translocation.

questions.text: During a dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), which of the following bones are typically removed?
questions.solution:
During a dacryocystorhinostomy, a portion of the lacrimal bone is typically removed to create a passage for tear drainage.

The lacrimal bone is indeed a key bone involved in dacryocystorhinostomy. In this procedure, a portion of the lacrimal bone is often removed to create a passage for tear drainage.

Other options:

Frontal (a): The frontal bone is not typically removed during a dacryocystorhinostomy. DCR primarily involves the lacrimal bone and sometimes parts of the nasal bone.

Ethmoidal (b): The ethmoidal bone is not typically removed during a standard DCR. The primary bone involved is the lacrimal bone.

Maxillary (c): The maxillary bone is not typically removed during a dacryocystorhinostomy. The main focus is on the lacrimal bone.

questions.text: A teenager is brought to the OPD with history of amenorrhea. On examination, she is short statured, has a webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck. Further examination revealed widely spaced nipples. Karyotyping in this patient would reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has turner's syndrome, with 45 XO.

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here)

  • Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest
  • Amenorrhea (primary), infertility
  • Barr body absent
  • Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema
  • L: Learning disabilities
  • Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome material is present)
  • Webbed neck
  • Nipples widely spaced
  • Horseshoe kidneys

The image below shows webbed neck.

Option D - 47 XXY: Klinefelter's syndrome occurs in males with a 47 XXY karyotype and is associated with testicular dysfunction and male infertility.

questions.text: What is the most probable vitamin deficiency anticipated in a pregnant woman who is on a strict vegetarian diet?
questions.solution:
Strict vegetarians are at risk of developing a nutritional deficiency of vitamin B12.

There are no plant sources as such for vitamin B12/cobalamine.

  • Vitamin B12/cobalamine is synthesized exclusively by microorganisms.
  • Vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin.
  • As a result, strict vegetarians are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin deficiency presents as anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils. Megaloblastic anemia is commonly caused by vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency and drugs that inhibit DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism. 

Other options:

B1 deficiency: A patient with thiamine or vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness, and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

B6 deficiency: A patient with pyridoxine or vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and normocytic anemia.

B9(Folate) deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency which leads to functional folate deficiency affects cells that are dividing rapidly because they have a large requirement for thymidine for DNA synthesis. Clinically, this affects the bone marrow, leading to megaloblastic anemia. Folic acid deficiency can also be seen in patients on prolonged use of metformin and can cause macrocytic anemia. Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe pain in her right index finger, back and legs along with fatigue. She states that the pain began suddenly about six hours ago. On examination, the patient appears pale and is grimacing in pain. A peripheral blood smear confirms the presence of sickle-shaped red blood cells. The biochemical analysis revealed high levels of indirect bilirubin. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and there is diffuse tenderness in the joints. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a Sickle cell crisis, which is a complication of Sickle cell anemia.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS). 

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    - Adolescence or early adulthood- auto splenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    - Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with a blackish lesion at the site of a mite bite from a few days back. He also gives a history of fever and rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, a history of mite bite followed by the development of a characteristic eschar at the bite site along with fever and rash suggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus. 

The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. 

Scrub typhus:

  • Most widespread Rickettsial disease
  • Mite is a vector
  • Vector – Trombiculid Mite
  • Causative agent – Rickettsia tsutsugamushi
  • Incubation period – 10–12 days
  • Typical clinical feature – Eschar
  • Weil felix reaction – is strongly positive with Proteus strain OXK
  • Treatment - Tetracycline

In Scrub typhus both the adult and nymphal stages of mites are free living in nature, hence they do not feed on vertebral hosts. The larval stage(chigger) feeds on the vertebrate host and pick up the rickettsiae. Rodents are the mammalian reservoir for scrub typhus. Eschar can be seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Anthrax- Cutaneous anthrax (Hide Porter’s disease) present as a black eschar at the site of entry. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–7 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The disease used to be common in dock workers, carrying loads of hides and skins on their bare backs. Renal involvement is unlikely to be seen in this condition.

The image below shows its characteristic rash:

Option C : Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a rickettsial infection transmitted by ticks (Dermacentor andersoni). It is the most serious type of fever. Symptoms include fever, headache, Rash, muscle pain and lack of appetite. Early treatment with doxycycline is recommended to prevent death and severe illness.

The rash is shown in the image below:

Option D : Epidemic typhus: Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and the vector is louse. Its incubation period is 10 to 14 days. The disease starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to the outpatient department with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with recurrent urinary infections or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.
